text: I'm Alex Scott.

And today I'm going inside an open plan lab
built by Shell,

the energy and chemicals company,
here in Amsterdam.

Open plan buildings and labs are becoming
the norm, with many pharma and chemical companies

looking to have their scientists work together
rather than separately in discrete rooms and
buildings.

CALIS: On that end we have experiments being
run, on that end we have offices, and in the

middle you see the connecting bridges with
the "strategic meeting points".

SCOTT: That's corporate-speak for "coffee
bars". About 900 scientists and engineers

in diverse disciplines work here. Shell thinks
that putting them into proximity, chatting

over coffee in the glass atrium, will lead
to productive idea-sharing. Some of that is
already happening.

SCHEFFER: Some time ago when standing on one of
the bridges across the atrium I saw a face

I hadn't seen in a long time, actually somebody
I knew from the days back in university. So

we sort of waved at each other and decided
to have a coffee. So by a chance meeting we

discovered that we actually have a lot of
technology in common.

Despite successes, not everyone thinks that
the transition's been perfect.

RAMAKERS: There are pros and cons for working
in an open office plan.

For example, Shell has had to ensure that
noisy people are grouped together so that

they don't disturb quieter workers. Site
manager Calis's hunch is that even with

such systems in place scientists working in
the building are happier and more productive.

And ultimately, that means more chance discussions
that could lead to great science.

I'm Alex Scott, reporting for Chemical & Engineering
News.
